An Open Letter To Mr. Hearst
FROM THE ASSOCIATION OF COLLEGE EDITORS
My dear Mr. Hearst:
In a recent interview, you challenged all Americans:
"If Americans have not lost their common sense and balance of judgment entirely, they will stop following sweet singers and smooth talkers
some day and settle down calmly and reason out a few things for themselves."
The Association of College Editors, as stated in its Covenant, is dedicated "to stimulating the interest of students throughout the world in promoting international understanding and cooperation in the hope of ultimately achieving and ensuring international peace and security .
A number of us are settling down calmly to reason a few things out
for ourselves. It struck us that one of the most pressing of today's problems is the controversy between "nationalists" and "internationalists."
You may recall that Beverly Nichols recently wrote a book called "Cry
Havoc." Determined to delve to the bottom of the controversy between
"internationalists" and "nationalists", Beverly Nichols hit upon the idea of
bringing together a recognized spokesman for each side.
Sir Norman Angell, probable winner of the Nobel Peace Prize for this
year, was selected and consented to brief the case for internationalism.
Lord Beaverbrook, owner of the London Daily Express and associated papers was asked to state the case for nationalism- .
Lord Beaverbrook wrote to Mr. Nichols: "If you will get Angell to ask
me questions, I will answer them."
Sir Norman Angell drew up a set of questions, a cross-examination of
nationalism. Nichols sent those questions to Lord Beaverbrook.

An Open Letter To Mr. Hearst

We Heartily Endorse

As I sit here devouring a bowl of
's choice vegetable soup, (with
Eugene Fish, N. S. L. member, on my
left) I am groping desperately for
some method of approach to the proble of war. I imbibe the soup; no solution comes. Thus, no soup.
Leaving aside the liquid lingo, the
NEWS-LETTER hereby volunteers its
full endorsement to the anti-war
conference, sponsored by a group of
Hopkins students, which is to be held
on the campus tomorrow afternoon
and evening.
Just what is this group attempting
to do? Primarily, it has called this
meeting as testimony to its detestation of war. But still more significant, it proposes to get to what it
considers the rotten core of international strife, and see if some means
cannot be devised whereby an end
might be put to the whole sorry mess
and a semblance of peaceful relations
be established between nations. Only
the most bigoted can frown upon
such a procedure.

A League of Nations, a World
Court, an international police, reciprocal disarmament, government ownership of munitions—all of these have
been advanced as prospective machinery for the termination of war.
Yet if any Of them is to prove effective, the citizenry of the nations

It strikes a great many American college editors as a singular and significant fact, that in the wording of those questions, the word "America"
may be substituted for the word "Britain"; the name "William Randolph
Hearst" may be substituted for the name "Lord Beaverbrook", without
altering the spirit of the questions, without lessening the tremendous importance to our generation of having an answer to those questions from the
most intelligent champions of nationalism.
Through the courtesy of Doubleday, Doran and Company, publishers of
"Cry Havoc", we reprint here the questions which Sir Norman Angell
drew up (the underlined words, the substitutions are mine, the questions of
my generation):

SIGMUND FREUD, father of psychoanalysis: "I abhor war, but I refrain from contributing a formula for
peace. I am all too deeply and painfully convinced of the futility of all
such demonstrations on paper."

NEWTON D. BAKER, former U.
S. Secretary of War: "I frankly have
no formula for peace and know of
none. I sympathize with and encourage every thoughtful effort toward
the promotion of international understanding, conciliation, arbitration, and
adjudication. Which of these efforts
is likely to be helpful even a little I
do not try to judge."
* * *
HAVELOCK ELLIS, British philosopher and psychologist: "Any single formula for the establishment of
a durable peace I should view with
suspicion. It is sure to be the concoction of a dogmatic theorist who
speculates in safety because his formula has never been put to the proof.
I speak from experience. When discussing The War Against War in my
book, The Task of Social Hygiene, I
elaborated seven powerful factors,
which all seemed to be working together for the abolition of war. Yet
not one of them so much as impeded
the outbreak of the Great War two
years later."

The significance, the importance of those questions is increased because there are two powerful men in two powerful contries to whom those
questions may be put as to one man. Particularly for that reason, they
must have an answer—not for the readers of the newspapers of either Lord
Beaverbrook or William Randolph Hearst, but for us, the generation of
young Americans who might have to fight another war if Lord Beaverbrook
and William Randolph Hearst happen to be wrong, if "preparedness" does
not preserve peace.
This whole letter of mine is being sent to the editors of 644 college
newsapers in America, and to the editors of the college papers in Canada,
for simultaneous publication as an open letter on or as near as possible to
the day of November 11, Armistice Day.
Yours is a tremendous influence in America. More than any other man
you represent the "Power of the Press". What you believe, you have the
power to lead millions of other Americans to believe. That is why it is so
tremendously important that you explain and defend "nationalism" as
opposed to the "internationalism" embodied in the spirit of the League of
Nations, to those of my generation who are about to believe—one way or
the other.
Yours very sincerely,
FRANCIS G. SMITH, JR.
Editor, The Daily Princetonian
President, the Association of College Editors.

The Liberal party was summarily
disposed of by the speaker as "a negligible factor in English politics at
present."
"As for the Labor party," he said,
"tnis group is quite a potential unit
but is afraid to make promises.
Among other things it stands for the
nationalization of banks and credit
institutions."
English Recovery Apparent
As to the economic conditions, Mr.
Emmart declared that England is
probably better off than any other
country in the world. He qualified
this statement with the remark that
there has been no absolute reduCtion
of unemployment, since it is estimated in official circles that approximately 2,000,000 men will continue
to be without work unless a sharp
increase is effected in international
trade.
"England has a definite fear of
three countries," he asserted, "although this fear is not necessarily
unfriendly. She is constantly following the movements of Japan, Germany and the United States."
Lists Psychological Traits
Among the psychological factors
which are noticeable in England today, the speaker listed: a feeling of
party pride and superiority; a dislike for the logical approach to problems, which the English brand as
counter to common sense; a love of
compromise, which has stood the
country in good stead on many occasions; and a romantic attitude and
approach, which, though latent at
present, will probably become more
manifest as problems arise.
"I advise you to observe England
closely during the next three or four
years," he told his audience in closing. "The reactions of the people to
situations of all types should prove
extremely interesting."

Articles judged to be outstanding in five branches of newspaper
writing for October are to be selected
from material published in the NEWSLETTER by the Pi Delta Epsilon committee today, it was announeed by
Hyman M. Levin, chairman.

To Judge Editorials
Levin said: "Even though the editorials of the Hopkins paper are
written exclusively by Stanley E.
Blumberg, editor-in-chief, the Pi Delta Epsilon, national honorary college
journalism fraternity, contest committee will choose the best editorial
of the month written by him."
The outstanding articles in the five
branches to be judged by the committee are to be considered for submission to the annual nation-wide
news and editorial contest sponsored
by the Grand Council of the national fraternity. The winner in each of
the two classes in this competition
receives $25. Other cash awards are
given. Nationally famous newspapermen who judge the Grand Council's
contest each year do not know the
Identity of the author or from what
college the article comes.

educational history ,decried false
economy in educational administration, declaring that it is endangering
the future of the nation's school
children. Dr. Weglein voiced the
same denunciation of false economy
asserting that if educators, municipal
and state governments failed to cooperate willingly in the carrying on
of only vitally necessary retrenchment in an "orderly and well-planned
manner," then the results would
prove disastrous to the future of tomorrow's citizens. The superintendent of public instruction added:
"The children in school today have
their only opportunity for education
and if this is denied to them at the
present time, their future will be irreparably damaged."

Following the assembly, a luncheon was held by the fraternity in
honor of Mr. Emmart. Dean E. W.
Berry was also a guest of honor.
Members of the fraternity who attended, in addition to Gordon and
Solarz, were: Robert McKericher,
John DeHoff, Melvin Goldberg, A. E.
Clark, Jr., John Reddick, Stanley E.
Blumberg, Philip Hamburger, Hyman
M. Levin and Ray Goldberg.

The names of the authors and subjects of the winning contributions in
editorials, sport stories, regular news
stories, editorial page features, and
news features are to be published in
the campus paper next Tuesday.

An Open Letter To Mr. Hearst
FROM THE ASSOCIATION OF COLLEGE EDITORS
My dear Mr. Hearst:
In a recent interview, you challenged all Americans:
"If Americans have not lost their common sense and balance of judgment entirely, they will stop following sweet singers and smooth talkers
some day and settle down calmly and reason out a few things for themselves."
The Association of College Editors, as stated in its Covenant, is dedicated "to stimulating the interest of students throughout the world in promoting international understanding and cooperation in the hope of ultimately achieving and ensuring international peace and security .
A number of us are settling down calmly to reason a few things out
for ourselves. It struck us that one of the most pressing of today's problems is the controversy between "nationalists" and "internationalists."
You may recall that Beverly Nichols recently wrote a book called "Cry
Havoc." Determined to delve to the bottom of the controversy between
"internationalists" and "nationalists", Beverly Nichols hit upon the idea of
bringing together a recognized spokesman for each side.
Sir Norman Angell, probable winner of the Nobel Peace Prize for this
year, was selected and consented to brief the case for internationalism.
Lord Beaverbrook, owner of the London Daily Express and associated papers was asked to state the case for nationalism- .
Lord Beaverbrook wrote to Mr. Nichols: "If you will get Angell to ask
me questions, I will answer them."
Sir Norman Angell drew up a set of questions, a cross-examination of
nationalism. Nichols sent those questions to Lord Beaverbrook.

We Heartily Endorse

As I sit here devouring a bowl of
's choice vegetable soup, (with
Eugene Fish, N. S. L. member, on my
left) I am groping desperately for
some method of approach to the proble of war. I imbibe the soup; no solution comes. Thus, no soup.
Leaving aside the liquid lingo, the
NEWS-LETTER hereby volunteers its
full endorsement to the anti-war
conference, sponsored by a group of
Hopkins students, which is to be held
on the campus tomorrow afternoon
and evening.
Just what is this group attempting
to do? Primarily, it has called this
meeting as testimony to its detestation of war. But still more significant, it proposes to get to what it
considers the rotten core of international strife, and see if some means
cannot be devised whereby an end
might be put to the whole sorry mess
and a semblance of peaceful relations
be established between nations. Only
the most bigoted can frown upon
such a procedure.

HAVELOCK ELLIS, British philosopher and psychologist: "Any single formula for the establishment of
a durable peace I should view with

I speak from experience. When discussing The War Against War in my
book, The Task of Social Hygiene, I
elaborated seven powerful factors,
which all seemed to be working together for the abolition of war. Yet
not one of them so much as impeded
the outbreak of the Great War two
years later."

The significance, the importance of those questions is increased because there are two powerful men in two powerful contries to whom those
questions may be put as to one man. Particularly for that reason, they
must have an answer—not for the readers of the newspapers of either Lord
Beaverbrook or William Randolph Hearst, but for us, the generation of
young Americans who might have to fight another war if Lord Beaverbrook
and William Randolph Hearst happen to be wrong, if "preparedness" does
not preserve peace.
This whole letter of mine is being sent to the editors of 644 college
newsapers in America, and to the editors of the college papers in Canada,
for simultaneous publication as an open letter on or as near as possible to
the day of November 11, Armistice Day.
Yours is a tremendous influence in America. More than any other man
you represent the "Power of the Press". What you believe, you have the
power to lead millions of other Americans to believe. That is why it is so
tremendously important that you explain and defend "nationalism" as
opposed to the "internationalism" embodied in the spirit of the League of
Nations, to those of my generation who are about to believe—one way or
the other.
Yours very sincerely,
FRANCIS G. SMITH, JR.
Editor, The Daily Princetonian
President, the Association of College Editors.

The Liberal party was summarily
disposed of by the speaker as "a negligible factor in English politics at
present."
"As for the Labor party," he said,
"tnis group is quite a potential unit
but is afraid to make promises.
Among other things it stands for the
nationalization of banks and credit
institutions."
English Recovery Apparent
As to the economic conditions, Mr.
Emmart declared that England is
probably better off than any other
country in the world. He qualified
this statement with the remark that
there has been no absolute reduCtion
of unemployment, since it is estimated in official circles that approximately 2,000,000 men will continue
to be without work unless a sharp
increase is effected in international
trade.
"England has a definite fear of
three countries," he asserted, "although this fear is not necessarily
unfriendly. She is constantly following the movements of Japan, Germany and the United States."
Lists Psychological Traits
Among the psychological factors
which are noticeable in England today, the speaker listed: a feeling of
party pride and superiority; a dislike for the logical approach to problems, which the English brand as
counter to common sense; a love of
compromise, which has stood the
country in good stead on many occasions; and a romantic attitude and
approach, which, though latent at
present, will probably become more
manifest as problems arise.
"I advise you to observe England
closely during the next three or four
years," he told his audience in closing. "The reactions of the people to
situations of all types should prove
extremely interesting."

Articles judged to be outstanding in five branches of newspaper
writing for October are to be selected
from material published in the NEWSLETTER by the Pi Delta Epsilon committee today, it was announeed by
Hyman M. Levin, chairman.

To Judge Editorials
Levin said: "Even though the editorials of the Hopkins paper are
written exclusively by Stanley E.
Blumberg, editor-in-chief, the Pi Delta Epsilon, national honorary college
journalism fraternity, contest committee will choose the best editorial
of the month written by him."
The outstanding articles in the five
branches to be judged by the committee are to be considered for submission to the annual nation-wide
news and editorial contest sponsored
by the Grand Council of the national fraternity. The winner in each of
the two classes in this competition
receives $25. Other cash awards are
given. Nationally famous newspapermen who judge the Grand Council's
contest each year do not know the
Identity of the author or from what
college the article comes.

economy in educational administration, declaring that it is endangering
the future of the nation's school
children. Dr. Weglein voiced the
same denunciation of false economy
asserting that if educators, municipal
and state governments failed to cooperate willingly in the carrying on
of only vitally necessary retrenchment in an "orderly and well-planned
manner," then the results would
prove disastrous to the future of tomorrow's citizens. The superintendent of public instruction added:
"The children in school today have
their only opportunity for education
and if this is denied to them at the
present time, their future will be irreparably damaged."

Following the assembly, a luncheon was held by the fraternity in
honor of Mr. Emmart. Dean E. W.
Berry was also a guest of honor.
Members of the fraternity who attended, in addition to Gordon and
Solarz, were: Robert McKericher,
John DeHoff, Melvin Goldberg, A. E.
Clark, Jr., John Reddick, Stanley E.
Blumberg, Philip Hamburger, Hyman
M. Levin and Ray Goldberg.

The names of the authors and subjects of the winning contributions in
editorials, sport stories, regular news
stories, editorial page features, and
news features are to be published in
the campus paper next Tuesday.
